1 Game Board.
1 Score Pad.
3 Counter's.
1 Rules Sheet.

Name: Overland Cross Country Race
Description:
Overland Cross Country Race Game


The Game is a "Race Game" around Britain stopping at 12 towns from London and Back.

Players take two balls each.

One ball is placed on the "Runway" and close to parallel. This allows the ball to run up and down the runway as it is raised or lowered.

When the all is over the desired town the runway is allowed to spring open to drop the ball to score.

Aim at each town in order using the two balls alternating until the player fails to score - The last scored ball remains in the board.

The next player then sets out. When he catches up with the other ball he can skip that town.

The first person to return to London is the winner.
 Contents

1 Playing Board with Metal Runway.
3 Balls.
Rules are Printed on the Inner Box Lid.

Name: Grocery Cart
Description:
Its time to go grocery shopping! Learn to do what wise shoppers do — scout ads for best buys! Grocery Cart involves players in four important life skills: comparing grocery ads, making correct payment for purchases, keeping accurate financial records, and reconciling cash on hand with shopping records. The winner is the player who makes the best purchases, makes correct payments, and keeps accurate records.

Two levels of play allow players in grades 4 and up to benefit. Eight grocery ads are included. Players are encouraged to substitute local ads to further increase realism.

Name: Managing My Allowance
Description: Managing My Allowance offers valuable first money experiences. Players use coins and bills to pay for purchases, compute change, handle allowances and gifts, collect earnings, and make deposits into college savings accounts. They are rewarded for accuracy, taking advantage of sales, saving money for college, and making thoughtful decisions. Transactions mirror the real world, adding value and excitement. Game variations offer two difficulty levels. In Allowance, the winner is the player with the most money in college savings. No financial transactions are recorded. In Managing My Allowance, players keep simple financial records. The winner is the player with the most money in college savings plus what is saved because of the sales.

Name: Making Change Octominoes
Description: Making Change Octominoes provides playful practice in counting money and making change! It also builds fluency in addition and subtraction. In Coin Values, players match the stated number of cents with a set of coins. In Making Change, players figure the correct change for a dollar and find a matching set of coins. Amazingly, both games are self-checking! The unique octagonal starting board offers eight positions for placing dominoes, intensifying learning. Additional games provide options for meeting specific needs.

Name: Coins Count!
Description:
"It’s fun to earn money for the food bank!”
Coins Count! is a valuable first experience in earning money for a charity, making small purchases, and handling change. Players become familiar with pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters, and dollar bills. The winner is the player who is the first to donate five dollars to the food bank. This rich instructional package also includes activities for use with an entire class: self-correcting lessons on making correct change and suggestions for interesting investigations.

Name: Budget
Description:
“I’ll never get out of this financial mess until I follow a Budget!”
Why not learn what it means to live by a budget? Before each trip around the game board, players plan a budget and receive $2,000. They experience the realities of real-life economics as they buy a home or rent an apartment, pay insurance costs, make investments, buy groceries and clothing, repair fire damage, collect commissions, etc. If the budget projection is reasonably accurate, the player collects a bonus on payday! The winner is the player who has the greatest wealth at the end of play.

Name: Decisions: A Stock Market Game
Description: “Shall I buy or sell? Am I a risk-taker or conservative investor?” What future earner will want to avoid investing in the stock market? Decisions is a money management game played in the context of the stock market. Players attempt to increase their wealth through strategic decision-making in buying and selling stocks. They rely, in part, on their sense of probability. The emphasis is on accurate computation and record-keeping. Players build communication skills as they explain the reasons for every move. The winner is the player with the highest net worth.

Name: GeoGems Polygons
Description: Discover the gems in geometry! Players develop fluency in naming and identifying the properties of six types of triangles, seven classes of quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and octagons. Builds geometric literacy through the use of words such as congruent, parallel, perpendicular, obtuse, acute, isosceles, equilateral, etc. Two name card sets and four property card sets offer progressive levels of play. Unique game board and moves multiply interest. Covers much of 2-D geometry content in state and national standards.

Name: PitchCar: Extension 4 – Stunt Race
Description:
This expansion for PitchCar lets you bring the car-flicking race game to a whole new level – literally. Yes, PitchCar: Stunt Race includes support blocks, ramps and track joiners – along with suggested circuits – that create a two-story race structure that will undoubtedly have your car sailing far beyond the rails as you gun the engine up the ramp.

Note, too, that the box cover shows a ramp support being placed in the center of the base level of track, providing an extra challenge on the ground – should working your arm through the supports in order to reach your car not be enough.

Expands:

    PitchCar (but not Carabande)

Name: Sauve-qui-peut
Description: Be the first player to reach the safety of your boat.  To escape the centre fortress you must climb onto the shoulders of another piece.

Name: High Finance
Description:
High Finance is one of six pencil and paper games described in the Sid Sackson book,  Calculate! .

Players advance through a series of game spaces and record the impact on their Net Worth according to the type of space they land on.  If the space simply designates one of four industries (Oil, Steel, Auto, and Food), then the player has gained control of one additional company in that industry and this tracked in a designated area of the scoresheet.  Upon landing on a "Profit" space, the player’s Net Worth is multiplied by a percentage amount that rises for controlling multiple companies in a specified industry.  Similarly the impact of landing on "Loss" space for an industry will be scaled according to the player’s holdings.

A mathematical operation is performed on the calculator for each player’s turn.  Examining the resulting display determines whether the player moves 0 to 3 spaces, although the player sometimes may have more than one choice to select from.  Game ends when all players have exited the sequence of spaces, highest Net Worth wins.

Name: Travel America
Description:
Travel themed trivia game about the 50 states of America. Game length is variable, depending on the starting and ending points players decide to travel.

Gameplay from box:
"Turn over a mileage card and the adventure begins. When you land, you answer a question about the state you land in. Get it right, and you go on -- collect your money or miles, but get it wrong and you pay. If you're the first traveler to reach the destination and you haven't gone bankrupt -- you win!"

Name: Maze Master
Description:
An updated take on the venerable wood maze and steel ball Labyrinth. Its dual pivot frying pan design, though, allows for single hand control.

"When you think you have it mastered, rotate the maze or switch hands and discover a completely new challenge!"

Name: Dinosaur Land
Description: Very simple roll (or, in this case, spin) and move children's game with a dinosaur theme. Ploddingly advance your dinosaur up the rainbow colored path to the finish line, hoping to avoid hazard spaces.

Name: Sadowa
Description:
Sadowa covers the one day battle (spread over 13 turns)  between the Prussians and the Austrians (and their Saxon allies) during the 1866 Bohemian campaign. Standard game (4 pages of rules), and a more advanced game with setup information (an additional 4 rules pages) with simultaneous plotting and some minor changes to the core system. Units represent infantry, cavalry, and artillery. Rules cover combat (ranged fire and close assault), line of sight, terrain, stacking, zones of control, redoubts, reinforcements, superior Prussian morale, optional Prussian Command, and Austrian "Kamikaze" Hussars!

Sadowa is a rather simple tactical design, with amateur production values, die-cut counters, and a color 22 x 14 inch map. Published by Fusilier Games (Aberdeen, Scotland), this game game was un-boxed (zip) with a cardboard cover sheet.

Name: Go for the Dough: The Game of Word Meanings and More!
Description: From the Box:  "Go for the Dough is a fast-paced, vocabulary building and word meaning (semantics) game for children Ages 4 and up.  This highly motivational board game helps children improve their word recall, word knowledge, describing skills, semantic flexibility, and phonemic awareness skills.

Name: Automany
Description:
Automany - The road hazard game

(Resume of the game from the publisher)

The Automany game consists of an unending road on which players travel by car and experience various misadventures. When on the way a player loses his car, he must get another one immediately either by purchasing or renting. He pays the registration fees along with the insurance premium and then resumes his way on the game board.

For the most audacious players who like to take chances, the game gives opportunities to launch into business (business squares) and eventually make money. But beware, the richest player is not necessarily the one who wins; a player without money, who succeeds in keeping his car till the end, has many chances to win.

Name: Spy Gear: Spy Wire
Description: Race against the clock to neutralize detonators and deactivate the explosive before it blows! In this fast-moving, suspenseful strategy game, players slide the wire tiles to make connections between their defuser and their opponent’s pegs, close the circuits, and deactivate their fuses. Comes with an electronic countdown timer and explosive sound effects that create sudden-death endings if you make the wrong move. Live to spy another day…there’s not a second to waste!

Name: The Moor was Covered in Blood
Description:
A miniatures wargame intended for classroom use with two teams of students (grades 6-8). The game is designed to be played on a 7.5x5 foot table using miniature figures mounted two per base. Free print-and-play paper miniatures are also provided for use with the rules.

“The decisive battle of the 1745 Jacobite Rising took place at Culloden in April, 1746. The English army had been strengthened by reinforcements from the continent, and well trained by the Duke of Cumberland. They were well prepared to fight the Jacobite forces of Prince Charles. The Jacobites were outnumbered, low on supplies, and poorly led in the battle. They were subjected to a deadly artillery barrage, and outflanked by the English. The battle was a disaster for the Jacobites, and ended the rising.”
Families: History: War of the Austrian Succession

Name: Lovagkor
Description:
Orginally published as Ismerd meg a lovagkort! ("Get to know the age of chivalry!") this Hungarian game is now available in an expanded version, sold also under the name of Lovagor - Itt te vagy a király! ("Age of chivalry - you are the King!")

Home Page: http://integraljatek.hu/html/lovagkor%20tarsasjatek.htm

Name: Se hva jeg kan!
Description:
(From the box - translated from Norwegian)

Se hva jeg kan! (See what I can!) is a trivia game for the smallest children.

There are many things which needs to be learned and set in systems. Here the children learn of concepts, language, spelling, rhymes, numbers, seasons, weekdays and colours in a fun way.

The game is designed for children who has not started school yet, and prepares the child for the concepts that is used in school. Some questions may be easy for your child, but the game also contributes to the child getting conscious of it's knowledge and the concepts it is based on, and gives a experience of mastering. The game demands an adult to participate.

Name: Konkurrer med vaskebjørnene
Description:
(From the box - translated from Norwegian)

Konkurrer med vaskebjørnene (Raccoon wash)

Come and join in the fun and hectic cloth wash chaos! The raccoons try to recover the right t-shirts for their sets of cloths  from the washing machines - the player first player to find the t-shirts on his/her three secret tiles wins the game. But... on the way to the washing machines your raccoon have to find the tiles that is needed to open the right washing machines. The raccoon may also find a lucky joker tile or get a chance to have a peek into one of the washing machines. Who will be the first to recover the right t-shirts for their set of cloths and win the game?

Name: Speedway: World championship formula
Description:
This title is presumably from around the mid-1970's; in the box front picture, Olsen and another rider are wearing safety vests by Vojens Speedway Center, which was founded by Olsen in 1975. Production number 15504.

The box cover shows a drawing and signature of Ole Olsen, the Danish world champion in speedway.

The game has borrowed the player pieces from the Swedish Tippa Speedway, but the actual gameplay and board is very different.

The board has depicted a 4 lane track in an oval form (as is the case in speedway) which are again divided into squares. Some of the squares are coloured in one of 6 colours - and the colours determine what happens if you land on them. One game lasts for 4 rounds, as in real speedway, but there are additional/optional rules for both team and league play.

The rulebook actually suggests that since the game "aims at following the real speedway rules as close as possible", the ideal number of players is 16(!) which seems like a huge number for an old-fashioned roll-and-move game like this.

Also, the rules in various languages are all signed by Ole Olsen, giving the impression that he actually designed the whole game(?).

Name: Niko
Description:
(From the box)

Niko, Julius, Wilma and Essie have gone out to play. They slide down the Icy Slide and suddenly end up on the lands of the Black Wolf – help them find a way back home!

You move freely on the game board by rolling the die. After finding two of your animal character’s treats from underneath the snowdrifts, hurry towards the Snowy Steps – but don’t let other players’ animals snatch your treats, and beware of the Black Wolf! The first one to reach the Snowy Steps wins the game.

Name: kippl
Description:
An abstract game combining piece elimination strategy with memory.

Players mix 12 tiles of their color face down in a square pattern and then reveal 2/3 by flipping them face up. The player with the fewest face up tiles in his color goes first. Each move consists of a die roll followed by the move of either one of his face up pieces or a face down piece in a series of horizontal or vertical hops onto other pieces or stacks of pieces, which ends by flipping the moved piece, and removing the piece (if any) the moved piece was on top of when it started. Players who cannot make exactly the number of steps rolled with any legal piece must pass. Once all players have passed, the game ends and the player with the most visible pieces his color wins.

Name: Butterflies are Free
Description: From the box:  Play Butterflies Are Free and you won't be catching butterflies ... you'll be setting them free!  Move around the cool game board and see who'll be the first player to let these brilliant butterflies go.  but the game's no walk in th park!  Land on "Take 2 butterflies" and you have to add more to your collection.
